title: 111_hr4559
content: Commission to review benefits for disabled veterans. The State Veterans' Benefits Commission is established to evaluate benefits provided by each state to covered veterans based on disability rating. The Commission is composed of seven members appointed by various officials. The State Veterans' Benefits Commission is composed of seven members appointed by different officials, including the President of the Senate, President pro tempore of the Senate, minority leaders of the House and Senate, and the President. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Qualifications include at least three disabled veterans and one medical doctor among the appointees. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are elected by the members. The Vice Chairperson of the Commission is elected by the members. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings are held within 30 days of each member's appointment, called by the Chairperson or majority members, with a majority required for a quorum. Members serve without pay, but receive travel expenses. The Commission members receive travel expenses and per diem in lieu of subsistence. The Commission has a director appointed by the Chairperson, who can also appoint additional staff. The director and staff are appointed according to civil service laws and paid accordingly. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed to carry out its duties under this Act. The Chairperson can procure temporary services and request personnel from federal agencies to assist the Commission. The Commission has the power to administer oaths, authorize members or agents to take necessary actions, obtain official data from US departments, use the US mails, and request administrative support services. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services for carrying out its responsibilities under the Act. Within 60 days of the initial meeting, the Commission must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Veterans' Affairs, including evaluation results, a ranking of States by benefits provided to covered veterans, and recommended benefit amounts for States. The Commission is tasked with providing recommendations on how States can improve benefits for covered veterans with disabilities rated total for disability compensation. The Commission will terminate two months after submitting the report to Congress. Under chapter 11 of title 38, United States Code, disability benefits are provided to veterans with impairments expected to last throughout their life.
